{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3551036,"name":"Joshua Truman","username":"jt4929","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jt4929/{size}/253887_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T05:24:54.819Z","cooked":"

Today, we were testing a climber system that utilized the MAXPlanetary gearbox. It consisted of a falcon driving into two 9:1 stages into a cantilevered pulley. The force on the output stage was so great, the screw holding the 1/2" shaft was pulled through the stage, rendering the typical method of screwing the hex shaft in useless. We are shifting our design to support the pulley from both sides, but the shipping time for a new output stage is fairly long. We were wondering if there were any teams out there who had experienced the same issue and if they were able to fix the broken stage. Our current leading ideas are using some sort of metal epoxy or maybe even welding it (can’t break it more ig).

Screenshot 2025-03-07 at 9.23.05 PM1266×1258 92.8 KB

Fun fact - you can absolutely break it more. We stopped using these after we found cracks and failures on ours and multiple other teams’ outputs in 2024 from moderate to the high load applications.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-08T08:58:57.337Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":93,"readers_count":92,"score":33.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494713,"topic_slug":"broken-maxplanetary-1-2in-hex-socket-output","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8002,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"177 & 429 | #TeamWCP| #TeamThrifty"},"post_url":"/t/broken-maxplanetary-1-2in-hex-socket-output/494713/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3551140,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T12:19:00.062Z","cooked":"

If you support the shaft at both ends, then as long as you fully constrain it at the far end, you don’t need to bolt it to the output stage; you’ve done what the bolt did – constrain the shaft axially. The shaft should be as short as possible.

Also, be aware that the 9:1 stages are weaker than the other MaxPlanetary stages, so that is a potential point of failure.

We avoid direct-driving high-stress devices like climbers. Instead, we have a separate shaft being driven by the motor/gearbox, and connect the two components with a cord (ie: a “climber in a box” mechanism without the box). That way you can run the gearbox at a much lower gear reduction and the forces on the gearbox are proportionately reduced. If you need two-way actuation, a spring/bungee/gas shock will do the trick (and also means the device is can give way if it gets hit).

We also upgrade the cord to auto seatbelt material; it’s easy to securely attach it at both ends, and ridiculously strong.
